security_audit.summary: This is a documentation-focused skill for skill authoring. It includes one utility script (render-graphs.js) that renders Graphviz diagrams to SVG using a hardcoded external command with no variable interpolation from user input. No sensitive data access, no network calls, no credential exfiltration risks.

low_findings.title: Utility script executes external command
low_findings.description: The render-graphs.js script executes the `dot` command from graphviz using execSync. While the command is hardcoded with no variable interpolation, executing external commands carries inherent risk. An attacker with control over the skill directory could potentially replace the graphviz binary. This is a standard utility for rendering documentation diagrams and poses minimal risk in context.

content.user_title: Create and test agent skills with TDD
content.value_statement: Agents often skip documentation or use skills inconsistently under pressure. This skill provides a test-driven development framework for creating skills that agents actually follow. Build skills using RED-GREEN-REFACTOR cycles, then pressure-test them to ensure compliance even when agents face time pressure, sunk costs, or authority conflicts.
actual_capabilities: Apply TDD RED-GREEN-REFACTOR cycle to skill creation
Create pressure scenarios to test skill compliance
Design effective skill descriptions for agent discovery
Use persuasion principles to close rationalization loopholes
Structure skills with progressive disclosure patterns
Verify skills work under time pressure and competing priorities
limitations: Does not replace understanding of the domain you are documenting
Does not execute skills or automate deployment
Requires manual testing with subagents to verify effectiveness
Best practices are guidance, not enforcement mechanisms

use_cases.title: Create new skills
use_cases.description: Document proven techniques using TDD methodology to ensure agents can discover and apply your knowledge effectively

use_cases.title: Standardize documentation
use_cases.description: Establish consistent patterns for skill creation across your team with testing requirements and quality checklists

use_cases.title: Improve skill compliance
use_cases.description: Fix skills that agents ignore by pressure-testing them and closing rationalization loopholes systematically

prompt_templates.title: Test existing skill
prompt_templates.prompt: Use the testing-skills-with-subagents skill to create 3 pressure scenarios for testing my [SKILL-NAME] skill. Run the scenarios WITHOUT the skill to establish baseline, then explain what rationalizations the agent uses and how to close those loopholes.

prompt_templates.title: Create new skill
prompt_templates.prompt: I want to create a skill called [SKILL-NAME] for [USE-CASE]. Walk me through the TDD cycle: first create failing scenarios, then write minimal documentation that addresses those failures, then verify compliance.

prompt_templates.title: Improve skill descriptions
prompt_templates.prompt: Review my skill description and suggest triggers, symptoms, and keywords that would help future Claude instances discover and load this skill at the right moment. Use the Claude Search Optimization guidance from writing-skills.

prompt_templates.title: Bulletproof discipline skill
prompt_templates.prompt: My [DISCIPLINE-SKILL] keeps getting rationalized away. Use persuasion-principles.md to suggest authority, commitment, and social proof techniques that would make the skill more resistant to agent rationalization under pressure.

output_examples.input: Create a skill for handling async test patterns
output: ‚Ä¢ Description: Use when tests have race conditions, timing dependencies, or pass/fail inconsistently
‚Ä¢ First, create baseline scenarios to see how agents naturally handle async testing
‚Ä¢ Write minimal skill addressing actual failures observed
‚Ä¢ Pressure test with time pressure + sunk cost scenarios
‚Ä¢ Close loopholes with explicit counters for common rationalizations

best_practices: Always run baseline tests before writing skills - watch agents fail to understand what needs preventing
Use concrete pressure scenarios with 3+ combined pressures (time, sunk cost, authority, exhaustion)
Document exact rationalizations verbatim and add explicit counters for each one discovered
anti_patterns: Writing skills without testing them first - leads to untested assumptions about what agents need
Using vague descriptions that summarize workflow instead of triggering conditions
Skipping pressure testing - agents follow rules in calm scenarios but rationalize under stress

faq.question: Which Claude tools support skills?
faq.answer: Skills work with Claude Code, Claude.ai conversational interface, and Claude API. Each loads skill metadata and reads SKILL.md files when triggered.

faq.question: How long should a skill be?
faq.answer: Keep SKILL.md under 500 lines. Move heavy reference material to separate files loaded only when needed using progressive disclosure.

faq.question: How do I integrate with existing workflows?
faq.answer: Reference other skills using their slug format. Add REQUIRED BACKGROUND or REQUIRED SUB-SKILL markers to establish prerequisites.

faq.question: Is my data safe with this skill?
faq.answer: This skill only processes markdown documentation. The utility script reads local files to render diagrams. No data is sent to external servers.

faq.question: Why do my skills get ignored by agents?
faq.answer: Most skills fail due to: weak descriptions, no pressure testing, or missing anti-rationalization counters. Test under realistic pressure to find actual failure modes.

faq.question: How does this compare to regular documentation?
faq.answer: Skills differ from CLAUDE.md in purpose and testing. Skills are reusable technique documentation requiring TDD-style verification. CLAUDE.md captures project-specific conventions.
